key_title: Key to the species of Echinochloa

Key to the genera of Poaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Spikelets loose to crowded, but not distinctly ranked, hardly gaping at maturity; leaf-blades usually under 12 mm wide
Spikelets crowded, distinctly ranked in 4–6 rows along dense, compact panicle branches, very turgid and gaping at maturity; leaf-blades wider than 1 cm (often 2 cm or more)
Primary branches of inflorescence with bristles subtending all or most of the spikelets; spikelets longer than 3 mm; leaf-blades not regularly red-banded
Primary branches of inflorescence lacking bristles, or sometimes a few present toward base, not subtending spikelets; spikelets less than 3 mm long; leaf-blades typically red-banded
Inflorescence drooping with flexuous branches; at least some branches of inflorescence with secondary branching (usually toward base of inflorescence)
Inflorescences upright with straight branches; the branches without secondary branching
Panicle usually fully exserted from upper leaf-sheath at maturity; fertile lemma tapered abruptly to a short (less than 0.5 mm), membranous, often recurved or distorted apical point
Base of panicle usually remaining enclosed by upper leaf-sheath; fertile lemma tapered evenly to a firm (but not hardened) apical point
Spikelets 3.2–4.5 mm long; fertile lemma and palea pale to mid-brown at maturity
Spikelets 2.5–3.1 mm long; fertile lemma and palea white to pale yellow or greenish, not brown at maturity
